instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good‚Äù and is required for the machine to power on & post..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
Working on a board that had liquid damage, and after replacing all questionable components, board had <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at .5v. Found the board had a shorted <TRANSISTOR>Q7320</TRANSISTOR>. Replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7320</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7321</TRANSISTOR>, and the short is now gone and I have a good 8.56v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, but I'm missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>. <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is present, but <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> and all my sustain signals are not present. No shorts found. <CHIP>U8020</CHIP> is covered in that protective conformal coating, and I didn't try replacing it yet, but if worth a try I will. I just figured since the liquid went near the CPU and shorted that MOSFET, that my CPU may be toast.

Should I waste any more time on this?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>.
threads.message: <TRANSISTOR>Q7320</TRANSISTOR> was shorted so that is pretty much end of the line. The <SIGNAL>SUS_L</SIGNAL> issue is probably something else, but the risk of dead CPU is too big to invest time in this board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
Thanks, duke. I figured as much, but like to run things by you. ;)

I actually need more 3437 parts boards, so not a big deal. Thanks!
